CENPA: The centromere-specific variant of histone H3. It is the fundamental epigenetic marker of the centromere, essential for nucleating the kinetochore complex to ensure proper chromosome segregation during mitosis. It replaces canonical H3 in centromeric nucleosomes.
CENPB: Centromere-binding protein B. Unlike CENP-A, this is a sequence-specific DNA binding protein that binds the 'CENP-B box' (a 17-bp motif) in alpha-satellite DNA. It aids in the folding of centromeric heterochromatin and stabilizes CENP-A/CENP-C interactions.
H1: The linker histone family. These proteins bind to the entry/exit sites of DNA on the nucleosome core particle and the linker DNA between nucleosomes. They are the primary drivers of higher-order chromatin compaction (stabilizing the 30nm fiber) and generally restrict access to DNA.
H1.0: A differentiation-specific linker histone variant. It accumulates in terminally differentiated, non-dividing cells and is associated with the formation of compact, repressive chromatin in somatic tissues.
H1.2: A replication-dependent somatic linker histone. Aside from chromatin compaction, it acts as a signaling molecule in apoptosis; upon severe DNA damage, it translocates from the nucleus to the mitochondria to trigger cytochrome c release.
H1.4: A major somatic linker histone variant. It is subject to specific post-translational modifications (like K26 methylation) that recruit heterochromatin protein 1 (HP1). It plays specific roles in regulating gene expression and mitotic chromosome condensation.
H1.4K34ac: Acetylation of H1.4 at Lysine 34. This modification is enriched at the promoters of active genes and is associated with the recruitment of the general transcription factor TFIID, specifically the TAF1 subunit, facilitating transcriptional activation.
H1.4S187ph: Phosphorylation of H1.4 at Serine 187. This occurs predominantly during mitosis (catalyzed by CDK1) to facilitate chromosome condensation, and during interphase to regulate rRNA transcription at nucleoli.
H1.5: A somatic linker histone variant often enriched in repressive chromatin domains. Its depletion leads to chromatin decondensation and aberrant gene expression, particularly in specific chromosomal repeats.
H1.X: A distinct linker histone variant that is less abundant than canonical H1s. It typically localizes to nucleoli and is associated with regions of high RNA Polymerase I activity, suggesting a role in ribosomal DNA transcription.
H1B: A linker histone variant (nomenclature often maps to H1.5 in humans or specific variants in mice). It functions similarly to other somatic H1s in stabilizing higher-order chromatin structures.
H1K27me2: Dimethylation of the linker histone (typically H1.4K26 in human numbering, often generalized). It serves as a binding platform for HP1 proteins, contributing to the formation and maintenance of facultative heterochromatin and transcriptional repression.
H1K85ac: Acetylation of the linker histone globular domain. This modification weakens the binding of H1 to nucleosomal DNA, promoting chromatin relaxation and facilitating the DNA damage response.
H1fnt: A testis-specific linker histone variant restricted to haploid spermatids. It is essential for spermiogenesis, specifically facilitating the replacement of histones by protamines to tightly package sperm DNA.
H1t: A testis-specific linker histone variant expressed during meiotic prophase. It binds chromatin less tightly than somatic H1s, creating a more open chromatin structure necessary for homologous recombination and meiotic processes.
H2: A general reference to the histone H2 family, which comprises the core histones H2A and H2B. These form a heterodimer that binds H3-H4 tetramers to complete the histone octamer.
H2A: One of the four core histone proteins. H2A forms a dimer with H2B. It has the largest number of known variants (e.g., H2A.Z, H2A.X) and its C-terminal tail is a critical site for ubiquitination-mediated silencing (Polycomb pathway).
H2A.B: A highly divergent H2A variant (formerly H2A.Bbd). It forms unstable nucleosomes that protect shorter DNA fragments. It is deficient in the inactive X chromosome (Barr body) and is associated with active transcription and mRNA processing/splicing.
H2A.Bbd1: A specific isoform of the H2A.B variant. It is enriched in the bodies of active genes and facilitates transcription elongation by lowering the stability of the nucleosome particle.
H2A.V: A specific histone variant found in Drosophila and other insects. It combines the functions of mammalian H2A.Z (transcriptional regulation) and H2A.X (DNA damage response) into a single protein.
H2A.VS137ph: Phosphorylation of Drosophila H2A.V at Serine 137. This is the functional equivalent of mammalian Gamma-H2AX; it rapidly marks sites of DNA double-strand breaks and recruits repair machinery.
H2A.X: A core histone H2A variant characterized by a unique C-terminal 'SQ' motif. It is the central component of the DNA damage response machinery, acting as a signaling platform around double-strand breaks.
H2A.XS139ph: Phosphorylation of H2A.X at Serine 139 (commonly known as Gamma-H2AX). This is the hallmark marker of DNA double-strand breaks. It is catalyzed by ATM/ATR/DNA-PK kinases and spreads kilobases around the break to recruit repair factors like MDC1 and 53BP1.
H2A.Z: An essential H2A variant conserved from yeast to humans. It localizes to the promoters of active genes and enhancers. It destabilizes nucleosomes to facilitate RNA Polymerase II recruitment and modulates the transcriptional responsiveness of genes.
H2A.Z.1: The major mammalian isoform of H2A.Z. It is essential for early development and is distinct from H2A.Z.2 by only a few amino acids, yet they show differential genomic localization and protein interactions.
H2A.Z.2: A specific isoform of H2A.Z (formerly H2A.V in mammals). It has distinct functions in neuronal development and is implicated in specific interactions with histone chaperones that differ from H2A.Z.1.
H2A.ZK4K7K11ac: Hyperacetylation of the H2A.Z N-terminal tail. This state is strongly correlated with active transcription start sites and open chromatin, preventing the deposition of repressive methylation marks.
H2A.ZK4K7ac: Acetylation of H2A.Z at Lysines 4 and 7. This modification marks active gene promoters and is associated with high transcriptional output.
H2A.Zac: General acetylation of the H2A.Z variant. This is a broad marker of active regulatory elements (promoters and enhancers) and is mutually exclusive with ubiquitination, which marks H2A.Z for repressive functions.
H2AK118ub: Ubiquitination of H2A (residue numbering varies; corresponds to K119 in humans). It is a repressive mark mediated by the Polycomb Repressive Complex 1 (PRC1), enforcing gene silencing.
H2AK119ub: Monoubiquitination of H2A at Lysine 119. This is the canonical repressive mark deposited by the RING1B subunit of Polycomb Repressive Complex 1 (PRC1). It inhibits RNA Polymerase II elongation and compacts chromatin to maintain gene silencing.
H2AK120Ub: Ubiquitination of H2A (often used synonymously with K119 depending on the organism or numbering convention). In humans, K119 is the canonical site; in yeast, H2B K123 is the ubiquitin site. Functionally linked to repression if on H2A.
H2AK130ac: Acetylation of H2A Lysine 130. A modification found in the histone fold domain, linked to the regulation of chromatin dynamics and transcriptional activation.
H2AK5ac: Acetylation of H2A at Lysine 5. This is an active chromatin mark found at promoters, often co-occurring with H2AK9ac. It is associated with transcriptional initiation and DNA replication.
H2AK9ac: Acetylation of H2A at Lysine 9. A specific marker of active gene promoters and regulatory regions, facilitating an open chromatin structure.
H2AS129ph: Phosphorylation of H2A Serine 129. This is the yeast equivalent of mammalian Gamma-H2AX (H2A.XS139ph). It is induced by DNA damage and is critical for recruiting repair complexes.
H2AS40GlcNAc: O-GlcNAcylation of H2A at Serine 40. This modification regulates nucleosome stability and has been linked to the DNA damage response and the prevention of excessive dimerization of H2A-H2B.
H2AT120ph: Phosphorylation of H2A at Threonine 120. This is a mitosis-specific mark catalyzed by Bub1 kinase. It is essential for the recruitment of Shugoshin proteins to the centromere, protecting cohesin from premature removal.
H2Aub: General abbreviation for Ubiquitinated H2A. Depending on the residue (usually K119), it serves as a major repressive mark utilized by the Polycomb machinery to silence developmental genes.
H2AvD: An older nomenclature for the Drosophila histone variant H2A.V. See H2A.V for function.
H2B: One of the four core histones. It forms a stable dimer with H2A. Its ubiquitination status (K120 in humans) acts as a 'master switch' to regulate methylation on histone H3 (K4 and K79), bridging transcription elongation and activation.
H2BK119ub: Ubiquitination of H2B (in yeast, this corresponds to K123; in humans, often confused with K120). If referring to yeast H2B, it is a prerequisite for H3K4 and H3K79 methylation and active transcription.
H2BK11ac: Acetylation of H2B at Lysine 11. An active chromatin mark found at promoters, typically catalyzed by Gcn5/KAT2A.
H2BK120ac: Acetylation of H2B at Lysine 120. It localizes to the promoters and enhancers of active genes, often distinct from the ubiquitination that can occur on the same residue.
H2BK120ub: Monoubiquitination of H2B at Lysine 120 (Human). Catalyzed by the RNF20/RNF40 complex (Bre1 homologs). This modification promotes transcriptional elongation, chromatin decompaction, and is required for subsequent H3K4 and H3K79 methylation (trans-histone crosstalk).
H2BK123ub: Ubiquitination of H2B at Lysine 123 (Yeast numbering). This is the functional homolog of human H2BK120ub. It is essential for H3K4 and H3K79 methylation and telomeric silencing.
H2BK12ac: Acetylation of H2B at Lysine 12. Associated with transcriptionally active chromatin.
H2BK15ac: Acetylation of H2B at Lysine 15. A mark of active promoters and DNA double-strand break sites, where it facilitates the recruitment of repair factors.
H2BK16ac: Acetylation of H2B at Lysine 16. Associated with the activation of gene expression and transcriptional start sites.
H2BK20ac: Acetylation of H2B at Lysine 20. This modification is enriched at active promoters and enhancers and is regulated by the CBP/p300 acetyltransferases.
H2BK5ac: Acetylation of H2B at Lysine 5. A mark of active chromatin found at promoters, associated with transcriptional activation.
H2BK5bhb: Beta-hydroxybutyrylation of H2B at Lysine 5. A metabolic epigenetic mark induced during ketosis/starvation that couples metabolic status to the activation of specific gene expression programs.
H2BP1me1: Monomethylation of H2B at Proline 1. A rare modification (N-terminal) whose function is not fully characterized, though proline methylation usually protects against degradation or alters protein interactions.
H2BS112GlcNAc: O-GlcNAcylation of H2B at Serine 112. This modification facilitates the monoubiquitination of H2B at K120, thereby promoting transcriptional activation and serving as a nutrient sensor.
H2Bac: Pan-acetylation of H2B. Refers to the general acetylation status of the H2B tail, universally associated with open, transcriptionally active chromatin.
H2Bub: General abbreviation for Ubiquitinated H2B (usually K120). A marker of active transcription elongation and a prerequisite for H3K4me3 and H3K79me.
H3: The core histone H3 family. The N-terminal tail of H3 is the most extensively modified domain in chromatin ('the histone code'), regulating transcription, repair, and replication. Includes variants H3.1, H3.2, and H3.3.
H3.1: The canonical, replication-dependent histone H3 variant. It is synthesized during S-phase and deposited into chromatin by the CAF-1 chaperone complex behind the replication fork. It is often enriched in silent or heterochromatic regions compared to H3.3.
H3.2: A canonical, replication-dependent H3 variant. It differs from H3.1 by only one amino acid (in mammals) but is chemically distinct. Like H3.1, it serves as a 'blank slate' for chromatin deposited during replication and is often found in repressive domains.
H3.3: The replication-independent H3 variant. It is expressed and incorporated throughout the cell cycle by chaperones HIRA (at promoters/gene bodies) and DAXX/ATRX (at telomeres). It marks active genes, regulatory elements, and telomeres.
H3.3 K27M mutant: A specific oncogenic mutation (Lysine 27 to Methionine) found primarily in pediatric high-grade gliomas. This mutant protein binds to and inhibits the EZH2 subunit of PRC2, causing a global reduction in H3K27me3 and aberrant gene reactivation.
H3.3B: One of the two genes (H3F3B) that encodes the H3.3 protein. Mutations in this gene specifically are linked to chondroblastomas and other distinct pathologies compared to H3F3A mutations.
H3.3K27me3: Trimethylation of H3.3 at Lysine 27. While K27me3 is generally repressive, its presence on the H3.3 variant (often at telomeres or developmental loci) suggests a mechanism for maintaining specific silencing memory in non-dividing cells.
H3.3S31ph: Phosphorylation of H3.3 at Serine 31. This residue is unique to H3.3 (H3.1 has Alanine). It is a mitotic mark specifically enriched on lagging chromosomes, potentially acting as a signal for chromosomal instability.
H3.5: A human-specific H3 variant expressed exclusively in the testis. It accumulates in the chromatin of spermatocytes and spermatids, co-localizing with H3.3, and is thought to regulate transcription during spermatogenesis.
H3.6: A designation often used for plant-specific or lineage-specific H3 variants. In Arabidopsis, H3.6 refers to a specific variant involved in flowering or seed development contexts.
H3.7: A putative primate-specific histone H3 variant. It is largely uncharacterized but shares sequence homology with H3.3, suggesting a role in specific developmental or tissue-specific gene regulation.
H3.Y: A primate-specific H3 variant structurally similar to H3.3 but unstable. It is incorporated into chromatin in response to stress and regulates specific gene expression programs, potentially relating to neuronal function or cancer.
H3K122ac: Acetylation of H3 at Lysine 122 (in the globular domain). Unlike tail modifications, this directly alters the histone-DNA interaction, destabilizing the nucleosome to facilitate transcription and chromatin remodeling.
H3K122sc: Succinylation of H3 at Lysine 122. A modification in the globular core that disrupts nucleosome stability and is associated with the DNA damage response and transcriptional activation.
H3K12ac: Acetylation of H3 at Lysine 12. A marker of active chromatin, often found at transcription start sites and CpG islands.
H3K14ac: Acetylation of H3 at Lysine 14. A well-characterized activation mark recognized by bromodomain proteins (e.g., BRD4, chromatin remodelers). It is associated with active gene promoters and elongation.
H3K14bu: Butyrylation of H3 at Lysine 14. A short-chain acyl modification linked to metabolic state. It stimulates transcription, often at rates higher than acetylation, particularly during spermatogenesis.
H3K14cr: Crotonylation of H3 at Lysine 14. A modification structurally distinct from acetylation that marks active promoters and enhancers. It can escape repression by certain deacetylases and drives strong transcriptional output.
H3K14me3: Trimethylation of H3 at Lysine 14. A less common modification than acetylation at this site, but linked to active transcription and super-enhancers.
H3K14pr: Propionylation of H3 at Lysine 14. An active chromatin mark associated with high transcriptional levels, structurally intermediate between acetylation and butyrylation.
H3K18ac: Acetylation of H3 at Lysine 18. This is primarily catalyzed by CBP/p300. It is a critical marker of active enhancers and promoters and is often used to map regulatory elements genome-wide.
H3K18cr: Crotonylation of H3 at Lysine 18. Associated with active transcription sites, particularly in the testis, and linked to metabolic regulation of chromatin.
H3K18la: Lactylation of H3 at Lysine 18. A modification derived from lactate (Warburg effect). It serves as a feedback loop where high lactate levels stimulate gene transcription involved in wound healing and M2 macrophage polarization.
H3K18pr: Propionylation of H3 at Lysine 18. Associated with transcriptionally active chromatin.
H3K18ub: Ubiquitination of H3 at Lysine 18. This modification is catalyzed by UHRF1 and is distinct from other ubiquitination events; it is associated with cell proliferation and DNA methylation maintenance.
H3K20me1: Monomethylation of H3 at Lysine 20. A complex mark associated with transcriptional activation, the cell cycle (highest in G2/M), and the X-chromosome inactivation process.
H3K20me3: Trimethylation of H3 at Lysine 20. A repressive mark characteristic of constitutive heterochromatin, particularly at telomeres and pericentric regions. It helps suppress repetitive DNA elements.
H3K23ac: Acetylation of H3 at Lysine 23. A mark of active chromatin, notably enriched at oncogene promoters in certain cancers and involved in DNA damage repair.
H3K23me1: Monomethylation of H3 at Lysine 23. While function is less defined in mammals, in C. elegans it is enriched during meiosis and regulated by specific methyltransferases.
H3K23me2: Dimethylation of H3 at Lysine 23. Implicated in the maintenance of heterochromatin and genome stability.
H3K23me3: Trimethylation of H3 at Lysine 23. Found in specific organisms (e.g., Tetrahymena, C. elegans). It functions as a repressive mark involved in heterochromatin formation and small RNA pathways.
H3K23pr: Propionylation of H3 at Lysine 23. Associated with active chromatin regions.
H3K23su: Succinylation of H3 at Lysine 23. A metabolic modification that alters the charge of the lysine residue, regulating chromatin structure and function.
H3K26me3: Trimethylation of H3 at Lysine 26. (Note: In canonical H3, Lysine 26 is followed by Lysine 27; this often refers to specific numbering in variants or older literature). Generally repressive if analogous to K27.
H3K27M: See H3.3 K27M mutant. The mutation can also occur in H3.1 (HIST1H3B), leading to Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma (DIPG). It acts as a dominant-negative inhibitor of PRC2.
H3K27ac: Acetylation of H3 at Lysine 27. The definitive marker of active enhancers (distinguishing them from poised enhancers which are K27me3+) and active promoters. Catalyzed by p300/CBP.
H3K27bu: Butyrylation of H3 at Lysine 27. An active chromatin mark that competes with acetylation and methylation at this residue, driven by metabolic butyrate levels.
H3K27me: General reference to Methylation of H3 Lysine 27. Usually implies the repression associated with the Polycomb pathway.
H3K27me1: Monomethylation of H3 at Lysine 27. Associated with active gene bodies and enhancers. Unlike me3, it promotes transcription and is often found in the vicinity of H3K36me3.
H3K27me2: Dimethylation of H3 at Lysine 27. A widespread repressive modification that covers large non-coding regions of the genome (intergenic silencing), preventing enhancer activity in inappropriate locations.
H3K27me3: Trimethylation of H3 at Lysine 27. The hallmark of facultative heterochromatin. Deposited by the PRC2 complex (EZH2), it silences developmental genes (like HOX clusters) in a reversible manner necessary for differentiation.
H3K27me3S28ph: Phosphorylation of Serine 28 adjacent to Trimethylated Lysine 27. This 'methyl-phospho switch' causes the ejection of Polycomb complexes from chromatin, allowing temporary activation of silenced genes during stress or mitosis.
H3K28ac: Acetylation of H3 at Lysine 28. (Note: H3 numbering shifts in some variants; in canonical H3, this is K27). If referring to a distinct residue in a variant, it is an activation mark.
H3K29ac: Acetylation of H3 at Lysine 29 (residue location varies by species/variant). Generally associated with gene activation.
H3K30ac: Acetylation of H3 at Lysine 30. Rare modification, function currently under investigation but linked to open chromatin.
H3K31ac: Acetylation of H3 at Lysine 31 (globular domain). Found in specialized contexts, associated with transcriptional activity.
H3K32ac: Acetylation of H3 at Lysine 32. Rare modification, function largely uncharacterized.
H3K34me3: Trimethylation of H3 at Lysine 34. A rare modification described in specific developmental contexts or organisms, potentially playing a role in cell fate decisions.
H3K36ac: Acetylation of H3 at Lysine 36. An active promoter mark, distinct from the methylation at this site which marks gene bodies.
H3K36me1: Monomethylation of H3 at Lysine 36. An intermediate mark found in coding regions of active genes.
H3K36me2: Dimethylation of H3 at Lysine 36. Localizes to intergenic regions and gene bodies. It acts to recruit DNMT3A to methylate DNA and prevents cryptic transcription initiation within genes.
H3K36me3: Trimethylation of H3 at Lysine 36. The hallmark of transcriptional elongation. It marks the gene bodies (specifically exons) of actively transcribed genes and prevents cryptic initiation by recruiting HDACs.
H3K4ac: Acetylation of H3 at Lysine 4. An active chromatin mark found at promoters, often co-existing with H3K4 methylation.
H3K4bhb: Beta-hydroxybutyrylation of H3 at Lysine 4. A starvation-induced mark that upregulates genes involved in the starvation response; links ketogenesis to gene expression.
H3K4me: General reference to Methylation of H3 Lysine 4. Universally associated with active or poised gene regulatory elements.
H3K4me1: Monomethylation of H3 at Lysine 4. The hallmark of enhancer elements (both active and poised). It is deposited by MLL3/4 complexes.
H3K4me2: Dimethylation of H3 at Lysine 4. A transition state often found at both promoters and enhancers. It generally marks a permissive chromatin state.
H3K4me3: Trimethylation of H3 at Lysine 4. The hallmark of active transcription start sites (promoters). It recruits the TFIID complex via PHD fingers to initiate transcription.
H3K4me3Q5ser: Serotonylation of Glutamine 5 adjacent to H3K4me3. This dual modification stabilizes the binding of TFIID, supporting high levels of gene expression, particularly in neuronal tissues.
H3K4ox: Oxidation of H3 Lysine 4. Generated by Lysyl Oxidases (LOX). This modification prevents K4 acetylation/methylation, serving as a repressive mechanism.
H3K56ac: Acetylation of H3 at Lysine 56 (globular domain). It marks newly synthesized histones during DNA replication and repair. It is critical for genomic stability and nucleosome assembly.
H3K5ac: Acetylation of H3 at Lysine 5. A marker of active chromatin found at promoter regions.
H3K64ac: Acetylation of H3 at Lysine 64 (globular domain). It is enriched at the transcription start sites of active genes and helps protect active chromatin from heterochromatin spreading.
H3K79homocysteine: H3 Lysine 79 homocysteinylation. A metabolic byproduct modification that competes with methylation at K79, potentially linking high homocysteine levels (vascular disease risk) to altered gene expression.
H3K79me1: Monomethylation of H3 at Lysine 79. Located in the core of the nucleosome (not the tail). Associated with active gene bodies.
H3K79me2: Dimethylation of H3 at Lysine 79. Associated with the coding regions of active genes and plays a role in cell cycle checkpoint regulation.
H3K79me3: Trimethylation of H3 at Lysine 79. Catalyzed by DOT1L. It serves as a marker of transcriptional elongation and is a critical activator in the Wnt signaling pathway and leukemia (MLL-rearranged).
H3K79suc: Succinylation of H3 at Lysine 79. A metabolic modification associated with the TCA cycle, linking mitochondrial respiration to chromatin regulation.
H3K9K14K18K23K27ac: Hyperacetylation of the H3 N-terminal tail at five lysine residues. This represents a maximally open chromatin state, typically facilitating very high levels of transcription.
H3K9K14ac: Dual acetylation of H3 at Lysines 9 and 14. A classic and potent marker of active gene promoters, utilized to recruit TFIID and chromatin remodeling complexes.
H3K9Kac: General reference to Acetylation of H3 Lysine 9. See H3K9ac.
H3K9S10me3: Likely refers to H3K9me3 accompanied by S10 phosphorylation. The phosphorylation of S10 during mitosis can mask the K9me3 epitope, displacing HP1 and allowing chromatin reorganization.
H3K9ac: Acetylation of H3 at Lysine 9. A distinct marker of active gene promoters. It is mutually exclusive with the repressive H3K9 methylation, ensuring that active genes are not silenced.
H3K9acS10ph: Phospho-acetylation of H3 (K9ac + S10ph). A hallmark of the nucleosomal response to MAP kinase signaling (e.g., EGF stimulation), marking immediate-early genes like c-Fos for rapid activation.
H3K9bhb: Beta-hydroxybutyrylation of H3 at Lysine 9. Links the metabolic state of ketosis to the upregulation of specific oxidative stress response genes.
H3K9bu: Butyrylation of H3 at Lysine 9. Marks active promoters and stimulates transcription, distinct from acetylation, often found in high-metabolism tissues.
H3K9cr: Crotonylation of H3 at Lysine 9. A modification that marks active promoters and enhancers. It is particularly enriched in post-meiotic male germ cells and drives gene expression more potently than acetylation.
H3K9la: Lactylation of H3 at Lysine 9. A lactate-derived modification that promotes the expression of homeostatic genes (e.g., in late-phase macrophage activation), serving as a metabolic clock.
H3K9me1: Monomethylation of H3 at Lysine 9. A mark found at active genes but also implicated in the boundaries of heterochromatin.
H3K9me2: Dimethylation of H3 at Lysine 9. A marker of facultative heterochromatin and broad silenced domains (like Lamina Associated Domains/LADs). Catalyzed by G9a.
H3K9me3: Trimethylation of H3 at Lysine 9. The hallmark of constitutive heterochromatin. It provides a high-affinity binding site for Heterochromatin Protein 1 (HP1), leading to tight chromatin compaction and silencing of repetitive elements.
H3Kac: Pan-acetylation of H3. Refers to the general presence of acetyl groups on the H3 tail, universally signaling open, accessible chromatin.
H3R17me2: Dimethylation of H3 Arginine 17 (CARM1 catalyzed). Associated with transcriptional activation, particularly of nuclear hormone receptor target genes.
H3R26cit: Citrullination of H3 Arginine 26 (catalyzed by PAD4). This conversion of arginine to citrulline reduces the positive charge, promoting chromatin decondensation. It is a key step in Neutrophil Extracellular Trap (NET) formation.
H3R2me2: Dimethylation of H3 Arginine 2. Its effect depends on symmetry; asymmetric dimethylation (H3R2me2a) is repressive as it prevents the reader of H3K4me3 (the PHD finger) from binding, silencing the promoter.
H3R2me2K4me3: Co-occurrence of H3R2me2 and H3K4me3. Usually, asymmetric R2 methylation inhibits K4me3 reading. Symmetric R2 methylation can coexist. This represents a complex regulatory switch at promoters.
H3R3me2: Dimethylation of Arginine 3 (Likely a typo in query; Arginine 3 is on H4. If referring to H3R2, see H3R2me2).
H3R8me2: Dimethylation of H3 Arginine 8. Associated with transcriptional repression.
H3R8me2s: Symmetric dimethylation of H3 Arginine 8. A repressive mark that recruits silencing complexes.
H3S10ph: Phosphorylation of H3 at Serine 10. It has two distinct roles: In mitosis, it is global and required for chromosome condensation (Aurora B kinase). In interphase, it is focal and marks active immediate-early genes (MSK1/2 kinase).
H3S10phK14ac: Phospho-acetylation of H3. This dual mark integrates mitogenic signaling (phosphorylation) with chromatin opening (acetylation) to drive rapid gene transcription in response to external stimuli.
H3S28ph: Phosphorylation of H3 at Serine 28. Similar to S10ph, it is a mitotic marker associated with chromosome condensation. In interphase, it can displace Polycomb complexes from H3K27me3.
H3S31ph: Phosphorylation of H3.3 at Serine 31. A mitosis-specific mark found on the H3.3 variant. It is uniquely enriched on lagging chromosomes in anaphase, potentially flagging DNA damage or segregation errors.
H3S57ph: Phosphorylation of H3 at Serine 57 (in the globular domain). Proposed to regulate nucleosome stability and higher-order structure.
H3T11ph: Phosphorylation of H3 at Threonine 11. A mark associated with transcriptional activation, androgen receptor signaling, and metabolic stress responses.
H3T3ph: Phosphorylation of H3 at Threonine 3. A strictly mitotic mark catalyzed by Haspin kinase. It recruits the Chromosomal Passenger Complex (CPC) to centromeres to ensure proper chromosome alignment.
H3T45ph: Phosphorylation of H3 at Threonine 45 (globular domain). Associated with DNA replication and apoptotic signaling.
H3T6ph: Phosphorylation of H3 at Threonine 6. This modification prevents the demethylation of H3K4, thereby protecting the active state of transcription against repression.
H3Y54ph: Phosphorylation of H3 at Tyrosine 54. A structural modification in the globular domain that can occlude the binding of specific chromatin factors.
H3ac: Pan-acetylation of H3. General activation mark.
H3mm11: A mouse-specific histone H3 variant. It is part of a cluster of variants involved in specific lineage programming during differentiation.
H3mm12: A mouse-specific histone H3 variant. Involved in developmental programming.
H3mm13: A mouse-specific histone H3 variant. Involved in developmental programming.
H3mm16: A mouse-specific histone H3 variant. Involved in developmental programming.
H3mm7: A mouse-specific H3 variant. It is essential for skeletal muscle differentiation and regeneration, incorporating into chromatin to regulate muscle-specific genes.
H3mmT: A mouse-specific, testis-specific H3 variant. Involved in chromatin remodeling during spermatogenesis.
H4: One of the four core histones. It is the most highly conserved histone protein. Its N-terminal tail is a major target for acetylation (regulating chromatin structure) and its K20 residue is a key methylation site.
H4K12ac: Acetylation of H4 at Lysine 12. A 'memory' mark; newly synthesized H4 is acetylated at K5 and K12 in the cytoplasm before deposition. In chromatin, it marks active regions.
H4K12me1: Monomethylation of H4 at Lysine 12. A rare modification with distinct functions from acetylation, potentially linked to specific repression pathways.
H4K16ac: Acetylation of H4 at Lysine 16. A unique modification that inhibits the formation of the 30nm chromatin fiber, causing decompaction. It is essential for dosage compensation (male X-upregulation) in Drosophila.
H4K20ac: Acetylation of H4 at Lysine 20. Associated with gene repression. It prevents the methylation of K20, thereby blocking the recruitment of specific readers like 53BP1 or HP1.
H4K20me1: Monomethylation of H4 at Lysine 20. Associated with transcriptional activation and cell cycle regulation. It is the substrate for subsequent methylation to me2/me3.
H4K20me2: Dimethylation of H4 at Lysine 20. The most abundant histone modification in mammalian cells. It serves as a binding site for 53BP1, playing a critical role in the DNA damage response (NHEJ repair).
H4K20me3: Trimethylation of H4 at Lysine 20. A hallmark of constitutive heterochromatin (along with H3K9me3). It suppresses repetitive DNA and transposons and is reduced in cancer cells.
H4K44ac: Acetylation of H4 at Lysine 44 (globular domain). Facilitates transcription by altering nucleosome-DNA interactions.
H4K4me3: Trimethylation of H4 at Lysine 4. A non-canonical and rare modification; function is currently obscure.
H4K58ac: Acetylation of H4 at Lysine 58 (globular domain). Regulates transcriptional response and nucleosome stability.
H4K5K8K12K16ac: Tetra-acetylation of the H4 tail. The hyperacetylated state of H4, associated with maximal transcriptional activity and open chromatin.
H4K5K8K12ac: Tri-acetylation of H4. A mark of active chromatin.
H4K5K8K16ac: Tri-acetylation of H4. A mark of active chromatin.
H4K5K8ac: Di-acetylation of H4. A mark of active chromatin.
H4K5ac: Acetylation of H4 at Lysine 5. A specific mark on newly synthesized H4 (deposition mark). In chromatin, it is associated with active promoters.
H4K5bu: Butyrylation of H4 at Lysine 5. Stimulates germ cell transcription.
H4K5cr: Crotonylation of H4 at Lysine 5. Marks active genes, particularly in haploid male germ cells, driving high expression.
H4K8ac: Acetylation of H4 at Lysine 8. A mark of transcriptional activation. It recruits the SWI/SNF chromatin remodeling complex.
H4K8bhb: Beta-hydroxybutyrylation of H4 at Lysine 8. A metabolic mark connecting ketosis to gene regulation.
H4K8bu: Butyrylation of H4 at Lysine 8. Associated with active transcription.
H4K91ac: Acetylation of H4 at Lysine 91 (core domain). It regulates nucleosome assembly and disassembly by weakening the H3-H4 tetramer interaction with H2A-H2B dimers.
H4R3me1: Monomethylation of H4 Arginine 3. A mark of transcriptional activation.
H4R3me2: Dimethylation of H4 Arginine 3. Effect depends on symmetry (see a/s forms).
H4R3me2a: Asymmetric dimethylation of H4 Arginine 3 (catalyzed by PRMT1). A mark of transcriptional activation.
H4R3me2s: Symmetric dimethylation of H4 Arginine 3 (catalyzed by PRMT5). A mark of transcriptional repression.
H4T71GlcNAc: O-GlcNAcylation of H4 at Threonine 71. A nutrient-sensitive modification with unclear functions.
H4Y88ph: Phosphorylation of H4 at Tyrosine 88. This modification alters the interaction between the histone octamer and DNA/chaperones, facilitating active transcription.
H4ac: Pan-acetylation of H4. General marker of open chromatin.
HINFP: Histone H4 transcription factor. This is NOT a histone protein, but a transcription factor that specifically regulates the expression of Histone H4 genes.
HTZ1: The yeast (S. cerevisiae) homolog of the histone variant H2A.Z. It localizes to promoters and prevents the spread of heterochromatin into active regions.
Pan lysine acetylation: A broad term for the detection of acetylation on any lysine residue across all histones. Indicates global chromatin opening.
Pan lysine crotonylation: A broad term for the detection of crotonylation on any lysine residue. Indicates a global metabolic-epigenetic state favoring transcription.
TH2A: A testis-specific variant of H2A. It is expressed in spermatocytes and is essential for the transition from histone-based chromatin to protamines during spermatogenesis.
TH2B: A testis-specific variant of H2B. It replaces somatic H2B in male germ cells. It destabilizes nucleosomes to facilitate the massive chromatin reorganization and histone-to-protamine transition in sperm.
TH2BS11ph: Phosphorylation of the testis-specific TH2B variant. Associated with chromosome condensation during meiosis.
hcp-3: The C. elegans homolog of CENP-A. It is the centromere-specific histone variant in nematodes.
hcp-4: The C. elegans homolog of CENP-C. It links the centromeric chromatin (hcp-3) to the outer kinetochore.
htz-1: The C. elegans homolog of the histone variant H2A.Z. Essential for gene expression regulation during nematode development.
macroH2A: A unique H2A variant with a large non-histone 'macro' domain attached to its C-terminus. It is generally repressive and is notably enriched on the inactive X chromosome in female mammals.
macroH2A1: An isoform of macroH2A. It acts as a barrier to reprogramming (e.g., in iPSC generation) and suppresses tumor progression.
macroH2A1.2: A splice variant of macroH2A1 that contains a macro domain capable of binding metabolites (O-acetyl-ADP-ribose). It links cellular metabolism (NAD+ levels) to gene repression and DNA repair (PARP pathway).
macroH2A2: An isoform of macroH2A. It functions as a tumor suppressor by silencing genes involved in cell migration and metastasis (e.g., in melanoma).
